eng: Global leaders have the power and moral responsibility to take bold actions and address the climate crisis facing us.
luo: Jotend piny mangima nigi teko mar loch kendo teko mar neno ni gitimo gigo madwarore mar neno ni gi kedo gi wach mar ketho aluora mar piny ma sani chandowa.

eng: Now is the time to end new expansion of fossil fuel production and invest in a transformational plan to ensure 100 per cent access to renewable energy across Africa.
luo: Sani e saa mar chungo medruok mar gero gigo ma golo iro, ka waketo mwanduwa e yoo ma nyalo kelo pogruok e ngima dhano mondo mi wa ne ni ji duto nigi kaka ginyalo tiyo gi gigo ma chiwo stima ma onge iro e Africa mangima.

eng: Now is the time for developed countries to put their money where their mouth is by honouring a commitment to mobilise at least Sh10 trillion (US$ 100 billion) annually to fund the mitigation and other climate change costs in the developing world.
luo: Sani e saa ma pinje ma ose dongore owinjore oket e mwandu gi kama dwarore ka gitomo gigo ma ne gise wacho ni gibiro timo ka gi golo omuom ma ok tin ne kwan pesa mar jo America maromo dola 100,000,000,000 e higa mondo okony e yore mag kedo gi gigo ma kelo lokruok e aluora mar dak dhano e pinje ma pod ni chien e weche mag dongruok.

eng: After all, Africa is responsible for less than 4 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions.
luo: Ka koro iwacho adieri, Afrika golo atamalo 4 mar iro mochido e piny mangima.

eng: We have seen the world mustering resources and efforts to ward off the global threat of the Covid-19 pandemic.
luo: Wase neno ka piny mangima golo mwandu mar kedo gi tuo mar korona.

eng: We saw the world come together to stop an arms race through the non-proliferation treaty of nuclear weapons.
luo: Ne waneno ka piny mangima ne otiyo kanyakla e keto chik matamo pije tiyo gi gige lweny manyalo nego ji mageny e piny – Neclear Weapons.

eng: It is now time for another treaty to save the world by switching off the fossil fuel era.
luo: Ochopo mondo piny mangima oket winjruok machielo manyalo konyo loro wach mar tiyo gi gik ma golo iro mangeny e piny ma ok ber gi ngima dhano.

eng: It’s digital all the way or you will be taken out of the game
luo: Sani koro gik moko itimo e yor mbuyi ma ka ok inyal to tich biro bedo matek ni!

eng: I recently stumbled upon an old photo showing a long and meandering queue of taxpayers outside Times Tower, Nairobi, waiting to submit their annual tax returns.
luo: Nyocha apo ka arodhno gi picha moro ma nyiso kaka ji yande riedo e laini mabor oko mar od solo osur ma iluongo ni Times Towers, Nairobi, ka girito mondo gi chiw duoko mag gi mar chulo osuru.

eng: Although the photo is not dated, it could have been years back before the Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA) automated filing of tax returns.
luo: Kata obedo ni picha no onge gi tarik, onyalo bedo higni ma machon ka ne bad Piny Owacho ma solo osuru – Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA) ne pok oketo timo tije gi e yor mbuyi.

eng: The long queue could have meant two things.
luo: Laini ma bor ni ne nyalo nyiso gik moko ariyo:

eng: It was either the last day or a few days to end of June when submission of annual tax returns falls due.
luo: Ne onyalo bedo odiechieng’ ma ogik or ndalo matin ka due mar Auchiel pok orumo ma owinjore obedi ni ngato ka ngato ooro e duoko ne mar chulo osuru e hik sirikal ma rumo e dwe mar Auchiel no.

eng: The situation in that photo got me wondering, what would have happened if submission of annual tax returns was still manual at this time when physical engagements have been restricted as part of the Covid-19 containment measures?
luo: Gima ne aneno e picha no ne okawa gi wuoro; ang’o ma de otimore ka de bed ni ooro duoko mar solo osuru pod ne itero gi ji ma ok e yoo mbuyi ahinya sani ma idwaro ni ji kik rom mang’eny nikech wach tuo mar Corona?

eng: Would this have called for taxpayers to line up at KRA offices in shifts to submit their tax returns?
luo: Iparo ni ma ne nyalo miyo jo sol osuru kone gi ni mondo ipang laini bang’ grup ka grup ka gi ooro ripot osuru gi?

eng: How safe would this have been for the taxpayers and KRA staff?
luo: Iparo ni timo kamano de obedo ma onge rach ma nyalo wuoke kuom jo sol osuru kachiel gi jo tich mar KRA?

eng: Thankfully, the iTax system is in place.
luo: Gima duong’ en ni ooro duoko mar solo osuru sani itimo gi e yor mbuyi (internet) ka okale chenro ma KRA luongo ni iTax system.

eng: iTax is a self-service system that enables taxpayers to conduct tax business such as personal identification number (PIN) registration, tax payment, ledger maintenance, application for tax compliance certificates and waiver application, among others.
luo: iTax en chenro ma ngato timo gimoro amora kende. Ma miyo jo sol osuru timo weche mag chiwo duoko kaka ng'ato osolo osuru machalo – dwaro namba ma ichiwo gi KRA – PIN, chulo osuru, neno ni ikano weche ni mag solo osuru maber, dwaro barua ma nyiso ni ise bedo ka ichulo osuru maber, kwayo mondo oweni chulo osuru gi mamoko.

eng: Taxpayers can do all these from the comfort of their homes or offices.
luo: Sani jo sol osuru nyalo timo magi duto ka gin e ute gi kata e ofis ma ok gidhi ka KRA.

eng: The iTax system is especially handy at this moment when taxpayers are filing their 2020 annual tax returns.
luo: Yoo ma ichiwo go duoko mar chulo osuru - iTax system sani koro ber ahinya sama koro ji chiwo duoko mag gi mar chulo osuru e higa 2020.

eng: It minimises physical engagements which go a long way in helping flatten the curve.
luo: Omiyo ji ok rom pile kaka chon ma konyo e yor duoko tuo mar Corona piny.

eng: Safaricom CEO, Peter Ndegwa holds the 2020 Global Mobile (GLOMO) Award, awarded to Safaricom by Global Systems for Mobile Communications Associations (GSMA) in recognition of Safaricom's outstanding contribution to the mobile industry.
luo: Jatend kambi mar Safaricom Peter Ndegwa sani koro nigi mich mar 2020 Global Mobile (GLOMO) Award ma omi Safaricom koa kuom riwruok mar piny mangima mar simbe ong'we yamo ma iluongo gi dho ngere ni Global Systems for Mobile Communications Associations (GSMA) ma puoyo tich maber ma Safaricom ose timo e tedruok mar ogwe yamo.

eng: Safaricom can now tap into the lucrative Ethiopian market after the country awarded an operating licence to a consortium that is led by the Kenyan telco.
luo: Safaricom koro nyalo tiyo e piny Ethopia ka piny no nyocha omiyo riwruok mar kembe ong'we yamo barua ma oyiene gi tich e piny no ka otel negi kod kambi man Kenya ma iluongo ni telco.

eng: This paves the way for the company’s expansion into Ethiopia, which has massive opportunities for growth owing to its over 112 million population.
luo: Ma omiyo kambi mar Safaricom no thuolo mar yaro bade nyaka Ethopia ma biro miyo omed dongruok nikech Ethopia nigi kwan mar ji maromo tara gana 112,000,000.

eng: This comes following a decision by the Ethiopian government to award the bid for a second nationwide telecommunication licence to a consortium that includes Safaricom and parent companies Vodacom Group of South Africa and Vodafone Group of UK.
luo: Ma otimore bang’ Piny Owacho ma Ethopia nyocha oneno ni gichiw barua mar ariyo mar medo keyo ongwe yamo e piny no ne riwruok mar kembe mag ogwe yamo ma achiel kuom gi en Safaricom kanyakla gi kembe mane onyuole - Vodacom Group mar South Africa kod Vodafone Group man UK.

eng: “The Ministry of Finance and the Ethiopian Communications Authority warmly welcome the award of one new telecommunication licence to the Global Partnership for Ethiopia, a private consortium of Safaricom (Kenya), Vodafone Group (UK), Vodacom Group (South Africa), DCD Group (UK) and Sumitomo Corporation (Japan) and Development Finance Cooperation (DFC) today,” said the country’s minister of finance in a statement yesterday.
luo: Migawo ma ochung'ne weche omuom e Ethopia kod bad sirikand no ma ochung ne weche mag tudruok e yor mbuyi nyo orwako gi mor chiwo barua mar tich ne riwruok machielo manyien ma olosi gi kembe ong'we yamo ma giluongo ni Global Partnership for Ethiopia ma otingo Safaricom (Kenya), Vodafone Group (UK), Vodacom Group (South Africa), DCD Group (UK) kod Sumitomo Corporation (Japan) ka achiel gi  Development Finance Cooperation (DFC) kawuono.” Ma nyo owachi gi minista mar pesa e piny Ethopia e barua ma burua ma nyo kete koke.

eng: According to senior government officials who spoke to news agencies, the consortium placed a USD850 million (Sh85 billion) bid to bag the licence.
luo: Kaluwore gi ler ma jo dongo matiyo e sirikal ochiwo ne jo fwap weche, riwruok mar kembe ma sani dwa chako tich Ethopia ne oket tara gana 85,000,000,000 mondo mi giyud burua mar tich.

eng: MTN International, backed by China, offered USD600 million.
luo: MTN International ma en kambi man gi bede ne e pinje ma opogore opogore ka oriwe lwedo gi China nyocha ogolo kwan maromo gi pesa jo America (dollar) million mia auchil.

eng: The Safaricom consortium pledged to invest another Sh800 billion over the next 10 years to roll out telecommunication services.
luo: Jog ma oriwore gi Safaricom nyocha oketo singo mar golo kendo kwan maromo pesa jo Kenya 800,000,000.

eng: “Global Partnership for Ethiopia is a consortium of reputable telecom companies providing service to over 750 million customers all over the world and committed to create new jobs, support the economy through introduction of new and efficient services,” said Ethiopia Communications Authority (ECA) Director General Balcha Reba.
luo: “Global Partnership for Ethopia en winjruok mar kembe ma ongere mag ogwe yamo m sani nigi jo ngiepo ma romo million 75 (75,000,000,000) e piny mangima; gin kembe ma temo mondo oyaw kunde ma ginyalo ndiko ji tich ka gikonyo e yor dongruok e piny kuom kelo yore manyien mag timo tich.” Ma nyo owachi gi jatelo mar bad sirikal mangiyo yore tudruok e piny Ethopia (Ethiopia Communications Authority (ECA) Migosi Balcha Reba.

eng: “I am also very pleased the consortium will invest $8 billion over the next ten years.”
luo: “Bende amor ni winjruok mar jo sim ogwe yamo no biro kelo e piny Ethopia kwan maromo pesa jo America million 8 (8,000,000,000) e higni 10 ma biro.”

eng: A customer holds a 3G prepaid sim card after buying the service from an Ethio-Telecom shop in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
luo: Ngato bedo gi gima iketo e sime (3-G Sim Card) ka ose ngiewe e duka mar Ethio-Telecom man Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

eng: The decision by ECA comes less than a month after the state regulator received two bids for two licences to roll out nationwide operations under the new market structure.
luo: Neno mar ECA mondo omi winjruok mar kembe mag ogwe yamo burua mar tich timore kapok dwe achiel orumo nyaka ne bad sirikal no yudi kwayo ariyo mar chiwo barua mar tich e bwo chik mane giketo manyien no.

eng: Securing the bid further puts Safaricom ahead of regional competitors MTN that bid for the licence alongside state-run Ethio Telecom.
luo: Yudo barua mar tich Ethopia kono omiyo Safaricom sani kor ni nyime ne kekbe mogo ma gi pimore e chiro machalo MTN ma bende dwaro burua machal kamano kachiel gi kambi mar sirikal ma Ethopia ma iluongo ni Ethio Telecom.

eng: “With over $8 billion total investment, this will be the single largest foreign direct investment into Ethiopia to date,” said Ethiopia’s Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed.
luo: “Keto kwan maromo pesa jo America million 8 (800,000,000) biro bedo pesa ma okongo biro Ethopia dichiel ma oa oko kuom jogo ma dwa timo ohala e Ethopia nyaka sirikand Ethopia chakre.” Ja tend sirikand Ethopia – Prime Minister – Abiy Ahmed nyo owacho kamano.

eng: Our desire to take Ethiopia fully digital is on track.
luo: Dwaro wa mar neno ni Ethopia obedo gi tudruok masani mar yor mbuyi dhi nyime maber.

eng: Global service providers have been waiting in anticipation for the liberalisation of Ethiopia’s telecommunications market that began more than three years ago when the Council of Ministers agreed to partial privatisation of Ethio Telecom and the issuance of two other operating licences.
luo: Kembe mag ogwe yamo matiyo e piny magima ose bet ka rito gi geno mondo piny Ethopia oyaw thuolo ne jo go ohala e yor ogwe yamo mane ochalkore higni adek ma ose kalo kane bura mar jotend migepe owinjore ni sirikal owe jomoko ongiew kaka ginyalo bedo jo kanyono e kambi sirikal miluongo ni Ethio Telecom kendo chiwo barupe ariyo ne joma dwa timo ohala mag weche tudruok.

eng: Ethio Telecom had 50.7 million subscribers as at January 2021, including 23.5 million data and internet users as well as 309,000 and 981,000 fixed broadband and fixed service subscribers respectively.
luo: Kar dwe mar Achiel 2021, Ethio Telecom ne nigi jo ngiepo maromo 50.7 million ka oriw gi 23.5 million ma tiyo gi sime kod joma tiyo gi yor mbuyi (internet) maromo 309,000 kod joma tiyo gi yore mamoko makwan gi romo 981,000.

eng: While inviting bids at the end of last year, ECA said service providers needed to comply with strict technical and financial qualifications to demonstrate the company had the capacity to manage a licence of its scale.
luo: Ka ne gi luongo kembe mondo oor kwayo gi mar goyo ohala e piny Ethopia e yore manyien mar tudruok, ECA ne owacho ni kembe ma goyo ohala machal kamano nyaka nyis ni gin gi lony maber kod pesa malongo ma nyalo miyo gi timo tich maber ma oromo gi barua ma ibiro migi.

eng: “Under these licences, service providers will have the right to provide any telecommunication service, including voice, text and data using any technology whether fixed or wireless anywhere within Ethiopia and to send and receive telecommunications to and from outside Ethiopia,” said the authority in its call for bids.
luo: “Kuom barua ma ibiro migi no, weg kembe go biro bedo gi thuolo mar timo tiche ma opogore opogore ma tiyo gi waya kod ma ok ti gi waya ei Ethiopia, manyalo bedo gi tudruok jok man oko mar Ethiopia,” Bad piny owacho ne ondiko kamano e sama ne gi luongo ji mondo oor kwayo gi.

eng: The winning consortium will be allowed an initial licence term of at least 15 years with the possibility of renewal.
luo: Jogo ma okalo maber biro mi barua mar tich mar higni 15, ka tin, ma inyalo bed negi.

eng: “In addition, the licences will provide each of the licensees the right to obtain access to scarce resources such as radio frequency spectrum, numbering and addressing resources and rights of way with considerations to the time frame to be allotted to the incumbent operator to complete frequency re-farming activities,” said ECA.
luo: Machielo, jogo ma omi barua mar tich go biro bedo gi thuolo mar yudo gik duto ma gidwaro ma biro miyo gi yot mar tich maber.

eng: Safaricom first announced it was eying entry into the Ethiopian market in 2017 but efforts to enter the market on its own over the past four years made little headway.
luo: Safaricom ne owacho mokongo ni gidwa donje e chiro mar Ethiopia e higa mar 2017; kata kamano, temo mar donje e chiro no kende owuon ma onge joma gimakore go ok ose bet mayot kuom hig ni agwen ma ose kalo.

eng: The consortium allows the firm to leverage on the resources of its parent company to roll out its suite of products that have proven hugely successful in the Kenyan market.
luo: Winjruok mar kembe go biro miyo gi thuolo mar tiyo gi mwandu gi ma gin go kuonde masani gi tiye machalo kaka gik ma gi uso ma ose dhi maber e chiro ma Kenya.

eng: According to Safaricom’s latest financial results for the year ended December 31, 2020, the company recorded Sh289 billion in revenue from M-Pesa Global, a 54 per cent increase compared to Sh164.7 billion recorded in 2019.
luo: Kaluwore gi chal mar Safaricom kaka ondiki e repod gi mar higa ma Tarik 31.12.2020, kambino ne oyudo milionde 289 (289 billion) mane gi loso e MPESA ma itiyo e piny mangima; ma ne en medruok mar tara gana 164.7 (billion) kuom pesa mane gi yudo e higa 2019.

eng: M-Pesa Global was created following a reorganisation that saw Safaricom and Vodacom acquire full control of the mobile money brand.
luo: MPESA Global ne oloso bang’ lokruok mane obede ka Safaricom kod Vodacom ne koro okawe kaka mar gi.

eng: The suspects are said to have promised to help the job seekers to secure jobs with, among other organisations, the National Police Service, National Intelligence Service (NIS), Kenya Ports Authority (KPA), and other government parastatals.
luo: Joma omaki go wachore ni ne osingo ne rowere ma dwaro tich ni gi biro yudo negi tiche kuonde ma opogore opogore machalo – ka obila (National Police Service), ka okwach kich (National Intelligence Service (NIS), joma golo gik moko e dho nam (Kenya Ports Authority (KPA), kod bede sirikal ma moko.

eng: Police in Nairobi are searching for a senior prisons officer implicated in a Sh200 million fake jobs racket.
luo: Okwach kich ma Nairobi sani dwaro ja ditto moro ma tiyo gi joka jela ma chilo mieno e wach pesa maromo miliion 200 (200,000,000) e wach mar wuondo ji ni omanyo negi tije

eng: Two suspects have been arrested and are helping the DCI with investigations.
luo: Ji ariyo ma ichich go ni nyocha otimo gima kama ose maki kendo sani konyo okach kich gi nono wach no maber.

eng: The officer is said to have conned hundreds of desperate job seekers of their hard-earned cash, in the pretext that they could help them secure jobs in Government.
luo: Jatelo ma tiyo ka Jela no iwacho ni ne okawo masowa gir joma ng’eny ma manyo tije ka onyiso gi ni obiro yudo negi tich e piny owacho (sirikal).

eng: DCI chief George Kinoti said the senior Prisons officer had been conducting the con game for the last 10 months.
luo: Jatend bad sirikal ma nono weche mag mibadhi e piny Kenya (DCI) Migosi George Kinoti nyocha owacho ni ja ditto ma tiyo e bad sirikal mar twech (jela) ne ose bed ka mayoyo ji pesa e yor miriambo kuom dweche 10 ma okalo.

eng: On Friday, officers from the DCI headquarters raided the suspect's home in Nairobi and recovered hundreds of fake job offer letters.
luo: Chieng tich Abich, polise ma oa e ofis maduong mar DCI ne odhi apoya e dala mar achich no man Nairobi ma ne giyudo barupe mang’eny mag miriambo moluong go ji e tiche ma opogore opogore.

eng: Also recovered from the house of the suspect are fake dollars amounting to Sh2.4 million.
luo: Polis bende ne oyudo e od achich no dollar mar jo America ma ok adieri maromo million ariyo gi mia agwen. Ksh 2.4 million.

eng: Kinoti said the racket also involved other junior officers, including a driver.
luo: Kinoti ne owacho ni wach mar wuondo ji e yor manyo tich no ne nitie jomoko bende mane tiyo gi achich maduong no mane oriwo nyaka jariemb mitoka.

eng: The driver is said to have pocketed Sh5.7 million from unsuspecting job seekers, who were required to pay between Sh300,000 and Sh400,000 to secure jobs.
luo: Wachore ni ja riambo no ne okawo pesa maromo million 5 kod mia 7 (5.7 Million) kuom joma dwaro tich mane idwaro ni ochul pesa mar manyo tich mane bedo e kind alufu 300,000 gi alufu 400,000.

eng: The suspects are said to have promised to help the job seekers secure jobs with, among other organisations, the National Police Service, National Intelligence Service (NIS), Kenya Ports Authority (KPA) and other government parastatals.
luo: Achich go wachore ni ne osingo ne joma dwaro tich go mar yudo tich gi jo polis - National Police Service, jo okach kich - National Intelligence Service (NIS), kod joma tiyo e dho nam - Ports Authority (KPA).

eng: Kinoti said one victim, a woman, was from Kiambu.
luo: Kinoti nyocha owacho ni ngama ne gi mayo no ne en mama moro ma odak Kiambu.

eng: She claims to have been conned of Sh800,000 and promised that her three children would secure jobs at the National Health Insurance Fund, Nairobi Metropolitan Services and the Kenya Ports Authority.
luo: Ne owacho ni ne omaye alufu mia aboro (800,000) kane osing’ ne ni obiro ndik ne yowuote adek ibiro yud negi tiche ka National Health Insurance Fund, Nairobi Metropolitan Services and the Kenya Ports Authority.

eng: The woman however reported the matter to the police after the contacts failed to respond to her calls and claimed that the job offers had been affected by Covid-19 restrictions.
luo: Mama no ne otero wach no ka polis ka koro jok mane konye no ok mak simbe, ka giwacho ni tije ma nyocha yawuote owinjore odhiye go koro ok nyal tomore nikech wach mar corona.

eng: Kinoti said the complainant filed a report with the police in January and investigations began.
luo: Kinoti ne owacho ni Mama no ne ondiko ripot gi polis dwe mar Achiel 2021 mane nonro mar wach no ne ochakore.

eng: Another group of victims who had paid huge amounts of cash to secure jobs were treated to drama when they were taken to the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport for a familiarisation tour.
luo: Joma moko maromo ji 60 ma bende ne ochulo pesa mang’eny mondo oyud tich, ne omi kiach ka ne oter gi e pao ndege ma Jomo Kenyatta International Airport mondo gine kama gidhi tiye.

eng: During the visit to JKIA, close to 60 victims were taken around what they were made to believe would be their new workstation.
luo: Seche mane gidhi kanyo, dhano ma kwan gi ne nyalo romo 60 ne owuoth go e pao ndege ka inyiso gi ni kanyo e kama gi thi tiye.

eng: They also received a lecture from a person alleged to be from the human resource department.
luo: Ne owuo kodi gi ngat ma ne owach negi ni ne tiyo kama indiko e ji e pao ndege kanyo.

eng: They were then directed to report to their new work station March 18, 2021.
luo: Bang'e ne okone gi ni mondo gi dhiye e tich Tarik 18 dwe mar Adek 2021.

eng: However, that would be the last time they heard from the person who helped them secure their jobs.
luo: Kata kamano, mano e saa mogik mane gi winjo e wach ma oa kuom jalo mane konyo gi manyo tich.

eng: “Dejected victims have since been trooping to our headquarters to file reports detailing how they unbelievably fell for the tricksters machinations," Kinoti said on Twitter.
luo: Jogo mane chuny go ongawore go ose bed ka biro e ofiswa ma dunong’ ndiko ripot kaka ne owuond gi marach. Kinoti ne owacho kamano e yor mbuyi mar Twitter.

eng: One crisp morning five years ago, armed with Sh500, 29-year old Nelson Mandela embarked on a fashion design journey.
luo: Chieng’ moro gi okinyi higi abich ma okalo, ka en gi shilling 500 kende, ja hig ni 29 Nelson Mandela ne odhi e wuoth mar ngiyo yor  rwakruok.

eng: He was new in the city and was excited about taking a gamble.
luo: Ne en wendo e dala mar Nairobi to ne omor mar temo hape.

eng: He crossed fingers and, like a South African namesake, took a leap into the unknown, armed with faith and confidence.
luo: Ne omiyo lwetene kendo kaka ja South Africa mane ochake, ne ochako timo gima ne pok otimo e ngima ne, ka en gi yie kod chir.

eng: Mandela walked into Gikomba market and bought two pairs of shoes each at Sh250.
luo: Mandela ne odhi Kikomba ma ongiwo wuoch tielo ariyo mar shilling 250 moro ka moro.

eng: When he came back to the Central Business district, he sold the shoes at Sh4,500 a pair.
luo: Kane oduogo e dier town mar Nairobi kama ji timo e ohala, ne ouso wuoch nego shilling 4,500 wuoche achiel.

eng: He was only two years old in Nairobi but seemed like he had identified a niche for himself.
luo: Ne ose dak mana Nairobi higni ariyo to nenore ni ne ose yudo tich ma onyalo timo mar konyruok.

eng: He was completing his supply chain management course at Kenya Institute of Management, but here was his heart falling for fashion.
luo: Ne ogik tieko tiegruok mare mar somo ngiewo gik ma itiyo e ofisi kama isome weche mag ohala - Kenya Institute of Management.

eng: And the shoes kicked it off perfectly, literally.
luo: Ouso wuoch gi ne omiyo ochako maber, gima nenore.

eng: Buoyed by the returns, Mandela, who later joined a fashion school, started buying and selling shoes to make profits.
luo: Ka en gi ilo nikech ohala ma oyudo e wi wuoche ka wuoche kuom wuoch ariyo mane ouso go, ne omedo ngiewo kendo uso wuoch mondo oyud pesa mar ohala.

eng: It was in the process of selling that he found excited clients asking him what outfits could match the shoes.
luo: E kinde mane ouso wuochi gi ema ne oyudo jo ngiepo ma penje kit lewni mane inyalo rwwak gi wuoch go ma owinjore kod gi maber.

eng: It was time to climb a step higher on the ladder.
luo: Saa ne ochopo mar idho ngas dhi maloyo ma oloyo.

eng: Mandela seized the opportunity and ventured into cloth production.
luo: Mandela ne okawo thuolono ma odoje e twango welni.

eng: Now, he owns Logical Clothing, a production house in Kimathi Street’s Eagle House where people order for classy, tailor made outfits.
luo: E seche gi en gi kambi ma iluongo ni Logical Clothing, kama ji twang’e lewni ma nengo gi tek man e ot miluongo ni Eangle House, e wang’a yoo ma Kimathi street, Nairobi.

eng: “This is what I wanted from the outset. I started selling shoes and in 2017 and now dealing with clothing. I pursued procurement in college, which I have never used in the field. My drive to make it in the clothing industry has driven me this far,” says the young entrepreneur, crisp in a suit he has made himself.
luo: “Ma e gima ne adwaro chakre chon. Ne achako uso wuoch to ka ochopo higa 2017 nyaka sani to atwang’o lewni. Ne asomo weche mag ngiewo gik moko e school ma ikawe kos ma pok atiyo go nyaka sani. Dwacha mar neno ni adhi maber e tweng’o ema ose kela kama sani antiere ni.” Wuoyi matin ma ja ohala ni ne owacho kamano ka orwako law sut ma otwang’o kende.

eng: His suits, which is what he majorly deals in, are priced between Sh13,500 and Sh150,000.
luo: Sude ne ma mano e gima otwang’o mang’eny, ouso e kind shilling alufu 13,500 kod 150,000.

eng: When a customer orders, he takes two weeks to work on the order and deliver.
luo: Ka ngato dwaro sut, okawo juma ariyo mondo olos ne ma oter ne.

eng: However, it takes longer with mass orders.
luo: Kata Kamano, kaw ndalo ma okalo kanyo ka oyudo tich mang’eny.

eng: “Some of these suits incur huge production costs. A suit I sold for Sh65,000 cost me around Sh50,000 to produce.”
luo: “Moko kuom sude ma aloso kaw pesa mang’eny; sut ma auso shilling 65,000 kawa shilling 50,000 mondo alosi.”

eng: Mandela, who specialises in corporate suits, wedding suits, events outfits, Ankara dresses for ladies, bridal dresses, khaki pants, and who also sells shoes and shirts, says that one of the most important things that every tailor should have is a production house.
luo: Mandela, ma ng’eny ne loso mana sude mag kembe, arus, lewni mag nyasi, lep mon, lep mon mag arus, lewni matindo mag endni, ma bende uso wuoch kod sede, wacho ni gima duong ma ngama kuocho nyaka bed go en kar tich.

eng: “People want a physical location where they can visit to see what is happening and can launch complaints. It gives them confidence in the business.”
luo: “Ji dwaro kama ngato tiye ma ginyalo bire mondo gi ne gima timore kendo gi wach gima gineno ka ok ber negi. Ma miyo gi bedo gi adieri gi tich ma itimo negi.”

eng: He has employed three tailors, one delivery person and an office messenger, and plans to create a bigger empire going into the future.
luo: Sani ondiko funde adek ma kuocho, ngat achiel ma tero lewni ne jo ng’iepo, ngat machielo ma loso kar tich; opango medo kar tich mondo obed maduong kaka ndalo dhi.

eng: “I came to Nairobi in 2014 and by the time I started this business, I was still very green in the city. I started off with Sh500. It was a gamble, but worthwhile. Since, I believe in myself and in every venture I pursue,” says the entrepreneur.
luo: “Ne abiro Nairobi e higa 2014 kendo ndalo mane achako ohala ni, pod ne an wendo ka. Ne achako gi shilling 500.  Ne en temo hap ngato; to aneno ka ber mondo atim mano! Chakre kanyo, sani koro ang’eyo ni anyalo timo gimoro amora ma aketo e chunya ni adwa timo.” Ja ohalo no ne owacho kamano.

eng: “I have a son and I do not want him to be ravaged by the misery poverty took me through.” Mandela says that he stands out because he is customer-centric.
luo: “An gi wuoyi to ok adwar ni en be one chandruok mane akale.” Mandela wacho ni odhi maber nikech ong’iyo weche mag jo ng’iepo maber.

eng: In my company, we are all about meeting the deadline and expectations of the customer.
luo: E kambi na, gima watemo timo maduong en neno ni waloso ne joma ng’iewo wa gik ma gidwaro e seche ma idwaro giye kendo loso gi maber kaka dwarore.

eng: I believe in customer satisfaction, which leads to referrals.
luo: An atemo mondo atim gima moro ja ng’iepo; ma ema miyo gi kelo na jo ng’iepo ma moko

eng: A satisfied customer will pass the good news to another potential one, creating a chain.
luo: Jo ng’iepo ma odhi ka mor biro lando tim maber no ne ng'at machielo ma nyalo ng'iepo; ma miyo ibedo gi ji mang’eny ma dwaro ni iti negi.

eng: We sell quality clothes; we do not edit photos to promote our brand.
luo: Wa uso lewni ma beyo; ok wang’i pichni man e buk mondo omed wa rieko mar tweng’o.

eng: Unlike many tailors, he is careful with customers’ money.
luo: Ok kaka jo tweng’o ma moko, en ngama odan’g gi weche mag pesa mag joma ng’iewe.

eng: A running joke in this country goes that unless one supervises his tailor and carries weapons that is threatening enough, the tailor will never deliver.
luo: Ngero mantie e Kenya en ni mondo ngato yud gima odwaro, nyaka eket jatweng’o ka-gi-ka kendo nyaka ibed ni gige lweny ma nyalo buge maber; ka ok kamano, ja twengo ok bi tieko loso ni nanga.

eng: “This industry requires discipline. Customers give us money in advance and if one is not disciplined, you will spend the money and end up grappling with unfinished clothes when delivery time comes.”
luo: “E twengo ka dwaro mondo ngato obed man gi luor. Jo tweng’o miya pesa chon, omiyo ka ngato onge luor maber, ibiro tyo gi pesa kata giko ne to ok ibi loso nanga marum e sama idware.”

eng: Among many other dignitaries that Mandela has dressed include Migori Governor Okoth Obado, Uriri MP Mike Ogolla, CIC Insurance Group General manager Jack Kionga, Natalie Mukundane (Executive Chairperson at African Youth Commission), King Kaka and the whole Kaka Empire and a lot of MCAs.
luo: Kuom jotelo ma Mandela ose twengo negi gin kaka Jetend Piny Owacho ma Migori Okoth Obado, ja od bura maduong ma Uriri Mike Ogola, Jatelo mar CIC insurance Jack Kionga, Natalie Mukundane ma en jatend joma tindo man Africa, King Kaka kod jogene duto kod MCAs – jo chung mag kor ng’wenge mang’eny.

eng: Some of the challenges he has to weather include dealing with rogue customers, but he has learnt to handle them.
luo: Gik ma seche moko chune ni nyaka kor one kaka otimo en loso gi jong’iepo ma tich gi tek; kata kamano, ose puonjore kaka onyalo wuoyo kod gi.

eng: Sometimes I face clients who do not want to pay.
luo: Seche moko aromo gi jo ng’iepo ma ok dwar chudo.

eng: Some complain about small details they feel do not please them and want to default payment.
luo: Moko kuom gi wacho kunde moko ok olosore maber ma ok mor gi ma koro miyo ok gidwar chudo.

eng: However, we strike a dialogue and are able to reach a solution.
luo: Kata kamano, wawuoyo awuoyo ma wa winjre maber.

eng: His role model is Robert Pauley III, famously known as The Wealth Guy, a New York City fashion designer who Mandela describes as a very talented and smart man.
luo: Ngat ma more en Pauley III, ma ongere kaka ja mwandu; ma tweng’o New York ma Mandela wuoyo kuome kaka chal ma Nyasaye omiyo rieko kendo ngat maler.

eng: Has he ever wanted to quit?
luo: Bende nitie ndalo mane ose dwaro ni owe gima otimo?

eng: In 2018, things were not going well as I was so hard pressed that I wanted to go back to my village in Uriri.
luo: E higa 2018, weche ne ok dhi maber ahinya ma chunya ne ogombo ni mondo adog dalawa Uriri.

eng: I remember I posted a photo of my son on social media around that time.
luo: Anyalo paro ni ne aketo picha mar wuoda e mbuyi e ndalo no.

eng: A person from my home village texted me, telling me how big a role model I was to a lot of people.
luo: Ngat moro ma ja korwa ne ooro na ote e yor sime, ka onyisa ni an ngat ma ji mang’eny oluoro ma miyo gi chuny mar tiyo matek e piny ka.

eng: Suddenly, I felt some kind of motivation. Someone had just confessed that I was an inspiration to them.
luo: Opoya nono ne apoka abedo gi chuny ma otegno, nikech ngato ne onyisa ni an ema ginena kaka ngat ma dhi maber ma gi dwaro ni mondo gi chal go.

eng: Which role model gets frustrated and goes home to sulk?
luo: Ngat mane ma ji nigi geno kuome ma piny tamo wang’e ma we gima otimo ma dhi dala?

eng: He says that he realised that they were so many people who admired him and quitting would frustrate more than just himself.
luo: Ne owacho ni bange ne ofwenyo ni nitie ji mang’eny ma mor gi tich ma otimo, omiyo weyo tich ne biro bedo gima rach ok ne en kende to ne biro nego chuny ji ng’eny.

eng: I stayed put in the city.
luo: Kuom mano, ne aneno ni adhi mana nyime gi tija e Nairobi.

eng: Ethiopia's telecommunications regulator awarded one operating licence to a consortium led by Kenya's Safaricom and Japan's Sumitomo, Brook Taye, a senior adviser at the Finance Ministry, said on Saturday.
luo: Sirikal ma Ethopia ose omiyo Safaricom, Kenya kod Sumitomo, Japan barua mar tich. Brook Taye, Ja ngat rieko ma tiyo e Migawo mar Pesa, nyocha owacho chieng’ Nyongesa.

eng: The consortium which includes Safaricom’s parent companies Vodacom and Vodafone, and the British development finance agency CDC Group, paid Sh91.9 billion for the licence, Brook said.
luo: Bedo achiel mar kembe ma oriwo kambi ma duong mane Safaricom ochaki ka oa kuome Vadacom kanyakla gi Vodafone kod kambi machielo ma iluongo ni British Development Finance Agency CDC Group nyocha ochulo mondo gi yud barua no kwan pesa maromo pesa Kenya shilling 91.9 billion. Brook ne owacho kamano.

eng: They edged out MTN International Mauritius, a subsidiary of South Africa's MTN Group which had offered Sh64.9 billion for the contract.
luo: Ne giweyo MTN International - Mauritius, ma en bad MTN Group ma South Africa mane oyie chulo pesa maromo gi Kenya millionde 64.9 (billion) ne tijno.

eng: The two were the only companies to successfully bid for the licence.
luo: Kembe ariyo go ema ne ooro kwayo gi ne tich mane ni Ethopia no.

eng: Nine other companies had expressed interest in the auction.
luo: Kembe ochiko ne onyiso gombo mar yudo tich no.

eng: The firms are Orange, Snail Mobile, Etisalat, Axian, Telkom SA, Saudi Telecom Company, Electromecha International Projects, Kandu Global Communications and Liquid Telecom.
luo: Kembe go ne gin - Orange, Snail Mobile, Etisalat, Axian, Telkom SA, Saudi Telecom Company, Electromecha International Projects, Kandu Global Communications kod Liquid Telecom.

eng: The nine are said to have dropped their interests in the latter stages of the process alleging lack of transparency and the fees the Ethiopian government was asking from them.
luo: Kembe ochiko go ne oweyo manyo tijno bange ka giwacho ni ne onge ler maber kuom chiwo tijno kendo pesa mane Ethopia dwaro bende ne ng’eny.

eng: In the bid requirements, the government wanted the telecommunication companies to build their own network infrastructure such as towers.
luo: Kuom gigo mane dwarore, sirikal ne dwaro ni kembe go obed gi chenro mar gero gik mane gibiro tiyo go e piny no kaka kuonde ma bocho mane gibiro kete gige gi mag tich.

eng: Africa's second-most populous country is hoping that the opening of one of the world's last major closed telecoms markets will create millions of online job opportunities.
luo: Ethopia ma en piny mar ariyo man gi ji mang’eny e Africa mangima nigi geno ni yawo chiro maduong mar ariyo e piny mangima e yore mag weche mbuyi biro miyo ji tije mang’eny ma itimo e yor mbuyi.

eng: As the licence fee, the consortium plans to invest up to Sh919.7 billion in infrastructure among other areas, Brook said, adding that it was expected to create between 1 and 1.5 million jobs.
luo: Kuom chudo mar yudo barua mar tich, riwruok mar kembe go nigi chenro mar keto alufu gadhi marom gi pesa Kenya 919.7 Milionde (billion) e gero kuonde tich gi gik mamoko – Brook ne owacho – ka omedo ni wach ni biro miyo ji tije ma biro chakre 1 nyaka million 1 gi nus – (1.5 million).

eng: The two will secure full operating licences, but will not be allowed to operate mobile phone-based financial services, government officials said last year.
luo: Kata obedo ni kembe ariyo go ibiro mi baruape mag tich, ok bi yienegi mondo gitim ohala mar oro pesa gi yoo ongwe yamo – sime (mobile phone) machalo MPESA, Jotend sirikal ma Ethopia nyocha owacho kamano higa ma okalo.

eng: The operator will begin with 4G services, Brook said.
luo: Kembe go biro chako gi 4G mar sime.

eng: We will soon open a bid for the remaining licence, said Balcha Reba, director-general of the Ethiopian Communications Authority.
luo: Ma chiengni, wabiro luongo kembe mondo oor kwayo yudo barua mar timo tije ma odong’. Balcha Reba, jatelo maduong ka Ethopia Communications Authority.

eng: Balcha said MTN's offer was deemed too low.
luo: Balcha ne owacho ni pesa mane MTN dwaro chulo ne ni piny.

eng: Businesses that previously depended on walk-in traffic or window shopping to make their money have been disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.
luo: Kunde ohala mane dhi nyime maber gi uso nikech joma ne ngiewo gige ne gin joma donjo mana kama gitiye kata joma ne iywayo gi gik ma olier e dirisa sani koro ok dhi maber nikech wach mar tuo mar Corona.

eng: Thanks to technology and the Internet, online shopping has become the lifeline for many businesses.
luo: En gima ber ni biro mar gik ma ji sani tiyo machalo internet kata sime, ngiewo gik moko e yor sime kata ka ingiyo e internet ema koro jo ohala mang’eny tiyo go.

eng: To avoid contracting coronavirus, many Kenyans have resorted to shopping online and goods are delivered at their doorsteps.
luo: Mondo kik ngato yud Corona, jo Kenya mang’eny koro sani ngiepo mana gi sime kendo gik moko ikelo negi nyaka dho ote gi.

eng: “Shopping patterns changed when Covid came, clients were skeptical about shopping online,” says Brenda Mugambi, an online entrepreneur.
luo: “Kaka ji ngiewo gik moko kor olokore bang’ biro mar Corona, chon ne ji oluor ng’iepo gi yor sime kata e internet.”  Brenda Mugambi, ma timo ohala e internet ne owacho kamano

eng: She says clients were mostly worried about their safety - whether it was safe to shop for clothes.
luo: Owacho ni jo ngiepo ne oluor ni ginyalo wito pesa – ka gi wuoro ni bende en gima yot mondo ngato ongiew nanga e yor mbuyi kata internet.

eng: “This was a blow to my business,” Ms Mugambi says.
luo: “Ma en gima ne omiyo ohanda odhi marach.” Nyadendi Mugambi wacho kamano.

eng: The fashion retailer, who runs an online shop called Starsjoaillere, started her business in 2015.
luo: Ngama uso lewni, ma uso gigene e yor mbuyi, e kambine ma iluongo ni Starsjoaillere, ne ochako ohande e higa 2015.

eng: “When restrictions were eased in the country, I saw a different trend again. I think it is because people could go out again. There was an increase in demand,” she says.
luo: Kane chike mag Corona odok chien matin e Kenya, ne aneno pogruok kendo. Aparo ni ma ne otimore nikech ji koro ne nyalo wuotho oko kendo. Dwaro mar ngiewo gik moko ne obedore.” Ne owacho kamano.

eng: In addition, many clients work from home.
luo: Mar ariyo, ji mangeny sani tiyo e odi.

eng: Operating online, she says, has eased the shopping experience for most of her clients as they can easily get what they want from the comfort of their couches.
luo: Timo gik moko e yor mbuyi kata gi sime, Mugambi wacho, sani omiyo joma ngi’ewo gige yoo mayot nikech koro ok ochuno ni nyaka gidhi ire, to ooro negi gima gidwaro e kuonde ma gin tie.

eng: She compares sales from the previous years before Covid: “Business was doing well prior to Covid, there was however an adverse effect when Covid came.”
luo: Owacho ni ka opimo kaka ohala mare ose bet: "Ohala ne ber ber dire mane Corona ne pok obiro; bang’e Corona ohala ok ose bet maber ahinya.”

eng: There was high demand before the pandemic but “our clients have lost jobs, others had pay cuts which in turn affected our revenues.”
luo: Ne jo ng’iepo ng’eny ka ne Covid pok obiro. “Sani ng’eny joma nyocha ng’iewo kuomwa nyocha owito tijegi; moko kuom gi ne ongad misach gi ma omiyo nwengo marwa ok ber sani.”

eng: “Starsjoaillere ensures customers are satisfied by maintaining proper channels of communication, seamless and speedy delivery of orders and quality products that suit their needs,” adds Mugambi.
luo: “Starsjoaillere temo neno ni joma ng’oepo kuom gi mor ka gi wuoyo kod gi kaka dwarore kendo ooro negi gik ma gidwaro mapiyo.” Mugambi omedo wacho.

eng: And like other digital businesses, online retailers are faced with technological challenges.
luo: Mana kaka ohala mamoko ma bende itimo e yor mbuyi, jogo ma timo ohala e yor mbuyi – online businesss – bende nigi gik ma chando gi.

eng: “We have clients who are still trying to adjust to the digital space. Some also question our authenticity as a business because we do not have a physical location,” Mugambi says.
luo: Wan gi joma pok ong’iyo gi gik ma itimoe yoo mbuyi – online business. Jo mamoko bende penjo ka ohala ma watimo en adieri nikech wa onge gi kama watime ohala ma inyalo yudwa.", Mugambi wacho kamano.

eng: Many people are also not connected to the internet, therefore their product marketing cannot reach everyone.
luo: Joma ng’eny bende onge gi simbe mag tudruok e yor mbuyi - internet. Kuom mano, ok ginyal chopo kuom ji mang’eny manyalo ng’iewo gige gi.

eng: Mugambi’s desire to cater for the needs of the modern woman inspired her to start the business.
luo: Dwaro mar Mugambi ni mondo otim ohala gi mon masani ne omiyo ochako kambi mar timo ohala.

eng: “I saw a gap in the market, it was a challenge to find exciting and affordable shops that would suit the modern woman,” she says.
luo: Owacho kama, “Ne aneno ka nitie kit ohala ma anyalo timo; kata kamano, ne en gima tek mondo ayud duka ma nengo ne yot kendo man kama ber mane nyalo moro mon masani."

eng: In 2019, a third-year student pursuing a course in biotechnology started an online shop; Thrift With Dola, with Sh3,000.
luo: E higa mar 2019, nyathi skul mane somo weche mag nonro ne ochako duka ma iuse e mbuyi – online shop ma iluongo ni Thift With Dola mane ochako gi shilling 3,000.

eng: Viola Dola adds to the list of other online retailers who sell second-hand clothes.
luo: Viola Dola en achiel kuom jogo ma uso lewni e mbuyi – online.

eng: Washed, ironed, folded to ensure the edges pop out, a little perfume if necessary; that is what sets a physical ‘mtumba’ and an online shop apart.
luo: Oluoki, ogo pas, oban mondo mi bethe gi onen maber, okete moo ma ng’we ng’ar ka dwarore; mano ema kelo pogruok kuom lep Mitumba miuso e duka kod mago ma iuso e yor mbuyi.

eng: From the same source, the only difference is how it is delivered.
luo: Ka ogol gi kamoro achiel, pok mantiere en kaka ichopo kuom ja ng’iepo.

eng: “My shop deals in official pants, mom jeans, corduroy pants, joggers, cargo pants, tops and blazers,” says Ms Dola.
luo: Dukana uso long' mag tich, longe mine, longe mag kaki, lewni mag tugo, yendni mag nam, lewni ma irwako malo kod koti mag chuo.

eng: She says online selling was convenient as she could not run a full-time business, and therefore saw no need to pay rent for a shop.
luo: Ne owacho ni timo ohala gi sime ne oneno ka ber nikech ne onge gi sa ma onyalo timogo ohala ma dwaro bedo machieng ni kuom mano ne ok oneno gima omiyo onego ochul pesa mar duka ma iuse.

eng: Dola enjoys the rush of getting new products to restock her shop. “I go to the market in the wee hours to ensure I get the best for my customers.
luo: Dola winjo maber ka oringo manyo gik manyien mondo oket e dukane. “Adhi e chiro okinyi mang’ich mondo ayud lweni mabeyo ne jogo ma ng’iewa.”

eng: “I go home, wash them, iron, decorate and take pictures to upload on my Instagram account, which is my shop,” she says.
luo: “Adhi e ot, aluokogi, agoyo gi pas, aketo gik ma miyo ginenore maber kato akete e kara mar uso mar Istagram.”  Owacho kamano.

eng: The first few weeks after Covid were tough for her because of the ban on the importation of second-hand clothes.
luo: Jumbe mokuongo bang’ donjo Corona ne obedo matek  nikech lewni ma ose rwaki ok ne oyie negi donjo Kenya ka.

eng: “People were not buying clothes because they were working from home,” Dola says. Most of her clients, however, were students.
luo: “Ji ne ok ng’iew lewni nikech ne gitiyo ka gin e ot.” Jok mang’eny mane ng’iewe ne gin nyithi skul wetene.

eng: “The purchases were great before Covid, and I moved to online when the pandemic came, and then gradually sales started improving. Going digital was a survival mechanism for me.”
luo: “Uso ne ber diere mane Corona pok odonjo; ne adhi uso e yor mbuyi sama ne Corona obiro kendo ma ne koro miya ji maber ma ng’iewa. Uso ‘online’ ne atimo mondo ane kaka ne anyalo konyora.”

eng: Dola can tell that her clients are satisfied from the feedback she gets, though the favoured way of shopping is still going to the physical shop and trying out clothes.
luo: Dola nyalo ngeyo ka jogo ma ng’iewo lepe mor kaluwore gi duko ma oyudo kuom gi. Kata kamano, uso maber to dwaro mana yawo duka ma ji nyalo pimo e lewni ka oromogi.

eng: “Some people don’t know their body sizes, hence they can’t buy online,” she says.
luo: “Jomoko ok ongeyo lewni ma romogi maber, omiyo ok ginyal ng’iewo e yor mbuyi.” Owacho kamano.

eng: An ICT survey conducted in 2016 by Kenya National Bureau of Statistics and the Communication Authority of Kenya established that 39 per cent of private businesses engage in e-commerce.
luo: Nonro mane otim gi joka Kenya National Bureau of Statistics ma kaw kwan mar dhano kod Communication Authority of Kenya ne oyudo ni 39 kuom 100 timo ohala e yor mbuyi kod sime.

eng: Martha Nyambeki a banana farmer harvests some of her bananas at Nyambaria Nyamira County on April 8, 2019
luo: Martha Nyambeki japur mar rabolo kayo – Nyambiria, e ngweng’ mar Nyamira tarik 8 Dwe mar Agwen 2019.

eng: On the Saturday of December 12, 2002, I was part of the sea of humanity that took over the entire of Eastlands from the airport, the Central Business District and Uhuru Park.
luo: Chieng’ ngeso mar Dwe mar Apar gi Ariyo tarik 12, 2002 ne an achiel kuom jogo mane okawo Eastlands chakre Paw Ndege ma Jomo Kenyatta International Airport, chung town kod Uhuru Park.

eng: There was an aura of change on the country’s top leadership.
luo: Ne nitie lokruok e telo mar kenya.

eng: The current president was the ruling party’s presidential candidate.
luo: Ker masani ne jachung’ mar riwruok mar siasa matiyo.

eng: The captain of the Opposition had been injured on a road accident days earlier and flown to the UK for specialised treatment.
luo: Jatend joma ne ochung’ kode ne ohinyore e wanga yoo dala moko ma okalo kendo ne oter loka UK yudo thieth.

eng: And he was returning home for the ballot that would end the 40-year-era of the independence party.
luo: Kendo ne oduogo dala mar goyo kura mane biro tieko higni 40 ma riwruok mar siasa mane okelo loch e Kenya ose tiyo go.

eng: At that time, nobody worried much that the captain was injured because around him was a robust team.
luo: E seche go, onge ngama ne chunye otho ni jatend joma pinge ne ohinyore nikech ne nitie jogo mane tiyo kode mane loso yore duto.

eng: The climax of the day was a chaotic rally at Uhuru Park late into the evening.
luo: Gima duong’ chieng’ no en romo mane ji dhi bedogo Ohuru Park go odhiambo.

eng: The import of my discussion today is from the speech of the then vice captain, the late Michael Kijana Wamalwa.
luo: Gima omiyo andiko en gima ne jalup jotend jo opposition ma ose nindo Wamwala Kijana owacho chieng’ no.

eng: In his wisdom, he had captured the essence of the moment with these words: “For a great leader to realise his greatness, he must stand on the shoulders of other great leaders.”
luo: Ka ne owuoyo, ne owacho weche gi: “Mondo jatelo ma lich lich ne onenre, nyaka ochung’ kuom goke jowete” ma nyiso ni nyaka konye gi jo-wetene.

eng: This statement sums ups the workings of an economic system. The economic growth that we measure under the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is a sum total of several independent variables interacting under the directive of top leadership in the country.
luo: Wach ni owuoyo kuom kaka nwengo piny chalo. Dongruok mar yuto mar piny ma iluongo ni Gross Domestic Product (GDP) en gima nyiso kaka gik moko itimo e piny e bwo jotelo mogik e piny.

eng: Extractive political institutions destroy the genius of economic forces to organise the national endowments, talents and the reward system to generate the desired economic outcomes.
luo: Siasa ma rach ketho gik mangeny e piny ma nyalo miyo piny bed gi dongruok maber.

eng: In the eyes of the late Wamalwa, for an economy to redistribute the national wealth equitably, then policy and political leaders must not only focus on the parts of the economy but also their interactions as a whole.
luo: Kuom kaka Wamalwa ne neno, mondo yuto mar piny oke e piny maromre, mano dwarore ni chike ma oketi kod jotend siasa nyaka ng’i kuonde ma kelo mwandu ne piny kendo kaka gi romo mondo gi kony piny.

eng: In the current regime, big infrastructure projects have been highlighted as the pillars of President Uhuru Kenyatta’s legacy.
luo: E sirikal ma sani tiyo, gigo ma oger ma dongo dongo machalo wang’ yore ema iwacho ni e gik madongo ma Piny Owacho otimo ma ibiro par go tich mar Ker Uhuru Kenyatta.

eng: Unfortunately, a legacy is not something that you can do projects towards, but the outcome of several daily activities happening across all government sections and departments.
luo: Kuom hawi marach, gima ngato otimo ma inyal pare go ka ose weyo tich ok en gero gik moko to en gima ji neno ni otimore e bede sirikal ma opogore opogore.

eng: Empirical evidence on economic development identify investments in physical capital, human capital, technological progress, natural resources and property rights, and political stability as drivers of economic growth.
luo: Gik ma nyiso dongruok mar piny nenore e dongruok mar gik ma oger, somo mar dhano, gik manyien ma sani itiyo go, mwandu ma nie loo, neno ni jopiny nigi duol kuom mwandu gi; kod neno ni piny okwe e yor siasa e gik ma miyo piny bedo gi dongruok kor ka yuto mare.

eng: On the other hand, government consumption spending, political and social instability, trade barriers and socialism reduce economic growth.
luo: Kamachielo, pesa ma Piny Owacho tiyo e chulo gik ma ok kel bedruok kaka misara kod marupu ma imiyo jotich, siasa marach kod tungni mar piny, gik ma miyo ohala ok nyal timore maber kod keto ni gik moko duto gin mwandu mar jopiny miyo piny ok nyal dongre maber.

eng: If these are the drivers and inhibitors of growth, how then do we appraise the preoccupation with the legacy projects?
luo: Ka magi e gik ma miyo piny dongore kendo nyalo tamo piny dongruok, ere kaka wanyalo keto e ratili mar pim, wach ma sani ji osiko ka wacho ni gedo mar wanga yore ema ibiro paro go jatelo ma tiyo sani ka oweyo tich?

eng: All sectors matter individually and collectively.
luo: Migepe duto dwarore ahinya kar gi kendgi kendo kanyakla.

eng: Investments in physical capital include machinery, tools and building that enhance workers productivity.
luo: Dongruok e gik ma igero oriwo masinde, gik ma itiyo go mag lwedo kod gedo mar udi ema miyo jotich medo tiyo matek.

eng: It is unacceptable that the economy is heavily reliant of subsistence farming using equipment of the agrarian era.
luo: Ok en gima nenore maber ni dongruok mar piny otenore mana e yor pur mar chiemo ma sani pod itimo gi gik machon ma nyaka nene!

eng: This implies that the country has failed to leverage on modern productive capacities to exploit her labour force.
luo: Ma nyiso ni pinywa ok nyal tiyo gi gik ma sani mana mondo mi gi hiny kata gichand jotich.

eng: Human capital refers to the combination of education, health and other non-physical assets of the nation’s workers to enhance their productivity.
luo: Sama sirkal kwano dhano kaka mwandu, gikwano gik ma ng'atno nigo monyalo tiyogo e kelo dongruok ne piny. Gigo oriwo sombe, ngima mar dende, kod nyalo mamoko ma en go ma ok nenre gioko.

eng: Relevant education that impacts economic growth is both formal and informal.
luo: Somo manyalo konyo e dongruok e yore yuto mag piny oriwo somo mar skul, kod puonjruok ma ng'ato yudo oko mar skul.
